Brown spots, freckles and pimples (treated with yi mu cao (Chinese motherwort) tu fang)
Medical Function: Removes stasis and generates new (blood) (去瘀生新)

Samples of Formulae: For brown spots, freckles and pimples: yi mu cao (Chinese motherwort) tu fang.

Notes:
Picture source: Taiwan Fulin Elementary School Atlas (台灣福林國小圖鑑).
Chong wei zi (茺蔚子) is the seeds of the plant; taste is sweet and nature is slightly cold. It is used in the same way as yi mu cao and can be used to cool the liver.

Fumaric acid (延胡索酸 / 反丁烯二酸)
Xi ye yi mu cao (whole plant): Total alkaloids about 0.05%; content of leonurine varies with flowering period: very little in early flowering; 0.01–0.03% in mid-July to August; highest up to 0.04%

Name: bai qian
白前
Botanical: Cynanchum stauntonii (Decne.) Schltr.ex Levl. (柳葉白前)
Gynanchum glaucescens (Decne.) Hand. Mazz (芫花葉白前)

Names in herb trade (Cynanchum stauntonii): nan bai qian 南白前, kong bai qian 空白前, e bai qian 鹅白前, e guan bai qian 鹅管白前

Geography: China: mainly Zhejiang, Jiangsu, Anhui; also produced in Hubei, Jiangxi, Fujian
Maladies Treated: Root and rhizome: cough due to influenza
Root and rhizome: asthma with abundance of phlegm
Root and rhizome (in Bai Qian Tang): long-standing cough with counterflow qi ascending (咳逆上氣)
Root and rhizome (in Bai Qian Tang): body edema (體腫)
Root and rhizome (in Bai Qian Tang): shortness of breath with distention and fullness (短氣脹滿)
Root and rhizome (in Bai Qian Tang): unable to lie down day and night, must lean against a wall (晝夜倚壁不得臥)
Root and rhizome (in Bai Qian Tang): throat often makes a 'water-chicken' sound (喉常作水雞鳴)
Samples of Formulae:
Common combination: Usually used together with Zi Wan (Aster root) and Ban Xia (Pinellia rhizome).

Bai Qian Tang (白前湯) [Wai Tai Mi Yao, 《外台秘要》]
Indications: Long-standing cough with counterflow qi ascending, body edema, shortness of breath with distention and fullness, day and night leaning against the wall unable to lie down, throat often makes a 'water-chicken' sound.
Composition: Bai Qian (Cynanchum root/rhizome) 6 g; Zi Wan (Aster root) 9 g; Ban Xia (Pinellia rhizome, washed) 9 g; Da Ji (Euphorbia root, sliced) 3 g.
Preparation and administration: Soak in 1 sheng (approximately 1 liter) of water overnight. The next morning, decoct to yield 600 mL. Divide into three doses and take.
Dietary caution during administration: Avoid lamb and maltose.
Contraindications: According to Ben Cao Jing Su (《本草經疏》): Contraindicated for cough with counterflow qi ascending that is due to qi deficiency where qi fails to return to the origin, and not due to obstruction and repletion of the Lung qi from pathogenic lodging. Do not use for cough due to qi deficiency without external pathogenic factors.

Name: bing lang
檳榔
Common: In island of Sumatra: pineng, pining (Batak Toba), pineung (Aceh), pinang, batang mayang, batang bongkah, batang pinang, boni
In island of Kalimantan (Borneo): ahat, gehat, taan, pinang
In island of Sulawesi: alosi, mamaan, nyangan, luhuto, luguto, puko roko, amongon
In islands Nusa Tengara and Maluku: bua, hui, soi, hualo, hual, soin, ua, wua, pua, fua, hua, palm
Other: bing men yao jian 賓門藥餞
da fu bing lang 大腹檳榔

Maladies Treated: Abdominal pain and bloating (脘腹脹痛)
Diarrhea with sensation of needing to defecate more (瀉痢後重)
Dosage: 6–12 g daily; 60–120 g when used alone for treating tape worms.
Samples of Formulae:
For treatment of glaucoma: Use betel nut pieces [bing lang (betel nut)] made into 1:1 eye drops. Instill 1 drop every 5 minutes, a total of six times; then every 30 minutes, 3 times; afterwards, instill 1 drop every 2 hours according to the disease. When intraocular pressure is controlled within the normal range, instill 2–3 times daily, 1–2 drops each time, to prevent recurrence. Effective for miosis and lowering intraocular pressure in acute and chronic glaucoma. It is better than pilocarpine in control of intraocular pressure, and compared to pilocarpine, the duration of the miotic effect is shorter. The irritation is slightly stronger than pilocarpine and causes mild pain and conjunctival hyperemia; the side effects completely disappear after a few minutes.

For treatment of various intestine parasites: Bake bing lang [bing lang (betel nut)] and make into powder. Use 7.5 grams per serving. Take with decoction of honey [mi (honey)] and green onion [cong (green onion)]. Classical record: “For worms in the viscera of long duration not healing (治諸虫在臟腑久不瘥者): bing lang half-liang (半兩, roasted) powdered; each time two qian (二錢); mix with a decoction of cong (蔥, green onion) and mi (蜜, honey) for administration.”

Seed: Alkaloids 0.3%–0.6%, all combined with tannic acid; main: arecoline (檳榔鹼); small amounts of arecaidin (檳榔次鹼), guvacoline (去甲基檳榔鹼), guvacine (去甲基檳榔次鹼), isoguvacine (異去甲基檳榔次鹼), arecolidine (檳榔副鹼), homoarecoline (高檳榔鹼).

Tannin about 15%: catechin (右旋兒茶精), epicatechin (左旋表兒茶精), procyanidin A-1, B-1, B-2 (原矢車菊素 A-1，B-1 和 B-2), arecatannin A and B series (檳榔鞣質 A、B 的兩個系列化合物). Both series consist of the monomer, dimer, trimer, tetramer, and pentamer of procyanidin.
Fat about 14%: lauric acid (月桂酸), myristic acid (肉豆蔻酸), palmitic acid (棕櫚酸), stearic acid (硬脂酸), oleic acid (油酸); small amount of bis (2-ethylhexyl) phthalate.
Amino acids: proline above 15% (脯氨酸佔 15% 以上), tryptophane (色氨酸), methionine (蛋氨酸), tyrosine (酪氨酸), arginine (精氨酸), phenylalanine (苯丙氨酸).
Sugars and others: mannose (甘露糖), galactose (半乳糖), sucrose (蔗糖), areca red (檳榔紅色素), saponins (皂甙).

References: [1] Zhong Hua Ben Cao 中華本草》
[2] Tai Ping Shen Hui Fang 太平聖惠方
